content.content: Increasing MIP efficiency community poll This post examines the current MIP proposal timeline and seeks the community’s opinions regarding adjusting the parameters. Current timeline for MIPs includes:  4 weeks (RFC) request for comment period ~1 week intermittent time  ~3 days of formal submission ~4 days of waiting time prior to ratification polls   2 weeks ratification poll for formal voting  We believe the current 7 weeks period is too long and inefficient. We’ve observed little forum activity after the first few days of initial proposals and then activity picking up again close to the formal submission window (likely somewhat inflated by GovAlpha posts confirming proposal status). Data presented in this post further supports this assertion. Further, the delegates have proven they can form an educated opinion during the shorter three-day votes. Therefore, we believe the delegates would still have sufficient time to form an educated opinion if the ratification poll period was shortened by one week following the Formal Submission period ending. RFC Data There have been over 1,300 total forum comments on the initial MIP proposals. Below is the breakdown of the number of comments in each week of the 4-week RFC cycle.  upload_e8609f0aea9ebeb4772d92e878769ec41206×364 18.8 KB   There is a very apparent “dead zone” of activity during weeks 2 and 3 of the RFC period. This aligns with our initial thoughts, as much of the hype and discussion around a proposal happens during the first week of a new post. Logically this makes sense as provide this initial opinion, and then discussion picks up again as the proposal nears the end of RFC and during the official vote. Given the lack of activity during weeks two and three of RFC and the responsiveness of the delegates, we believe it would be quite reasonable to reduce the overall MIP timeline as follows: Suggested timeline for MIPs:  3 weeks (RFC) request for comment period  4 days intermittent time 3 days of formal submission   1 day of waiting time prior to ratification polls. 1 week ratification poll for formal voting  Polls We’d like to gauge community sentiment below for each of the three proposed timeline changes. Poll 1: Decrease the RFC period from 4 weeks to 3 weeks.     Option 1: Keep 4 weeks Option 2: Change to 3 weeks Option 3: Abstain     0 voters     Poll 2: Decrease the formal submission intermittent window from ~1 week to 4 days.     Option 1: Keep ~1 week Option 2: Change to 4 days Option 3: Abstain     0 voters     Poll 3: Decrease MIP proposals’ formal ratification polling period. Options to reduce to 10 days and 7 days are included.     Option 1: Keep 2 weeks Option 2: Change to 10 days Option 3: Change to 1 week (7 days) Option 4: Abstain     0 voters     @Recognized-Delegates @Core-Facilitators

content.content: Governance is a product with multiple stakeholders. In order to evaluate if this change is appropriate, we would first want to determine the appropriate dependent variable to measure. In order to do this, we could perform qualitative interviews with the stakeholders. Based on these initial findings, we can help inform what variables we would look to invalidate our hypothesis ( if we still believe these are dead periods after interviewing). Starting with initial interviewing lends support and rationale to the selection of our dependent variable (DV). In other words, deciding what the appropriate measures are to evaluate our hypothesis. (Shortening the governance period will produce more “efficient” governance.) How do we measure “efficiency”?  Based on the above it is implied based on comment count across a term. The inference I draw from the above data is simply that work is happening, but not visible via the operationalizations (DV) you have selected (comments). If your hypothesis is that there is low activity, you could vary your DV to see if the hypothesis still stands (eg. views, polling core units or recent MIP authors, etc). This could be done in the manner above (qualitative interviews) or varying your operationalization/DV (quantitative measure). From there, you would have a better picture and it would be evident in the signal request if the parameters would benefit from modification because your hypothesis has different operationalizations and significant data while it is still standing (affords construct and convergent validity). Even if a change is to be implemented, we need a hypothesis to measure improvement, based on what we have here, measuring comments, the implied hypothesis is that you would have the same or greater comments during the shorter term? It is advisable to establish hypotheses upfront when running these kinds of experiments such that you can evaluate their success (or failure) without post-hoc theorizing.

content.content: To be fair, all the work is well-intentioned, but there is a process when you approach theory building and governance could use it as we are building these experiments on implied theory that should be made explicit in order to be evaluated.  We would do best to use mixed methods to establish validity and how we will evaluate hypotheses and the performance of any governance changes. According to McGrath (1982),  “…all research strategies  are  seriously  flawed,   often  with  their  very strengths in regard to one desideratum functioning as serious  weaknesses  in  regard  to  other,  equally  important goals. Indeed, it is not possible, in principle, to do ‘good’(that is methodologically  sound) research”  (p.  70). McGrath,   Joseph   E.   (1982),   “Dilemmatics:   The   Study  of Choices  and Dilemmas,” in Judgment Calls  in Research, Joseph E.  McGrath,  Joanne Martin,  and Richard A.  Kulka, eds. content.content: Sometimes the glacial pace of governance is a feature not a flaw. When decisions have high impact and high risk, it is better to have them move more slowly where possible. Part of disinformation or governance exploits is to get high impact decisions to move quickly (reducing the chance they are caught or getting foot in door) or by slowing decisions that need to be done quickly (e.g. rate adjustments via SR). A taxonomy of governance actions (e.g. MIP, SR, etc), their use cases, and their attributes with a rationale makes sense and is needed if this interests your delegation. Aligning distinct governance actions to a a phased cadence could be a step forward, rather than changing the global governance cadence for all governance actions.

content.content: Hi Jun, Thanks for posting this thread, it’s always useful to consider whether optimisations can be made, and GovAlpha will be watching this discussion with interest. I just wanted to take the time to address the following:     Juanbug:  ~1 week intermittent time  ~3 days of formal submission ~4 days of waiting time prior to ratification polls    Regarding the 4 days of waiting time, bear in mind 2 of these days are the weekend. The remaining time is used by GovAlpha to ensure the following:  The MIP has been presented as formally submitted on a G&R call (a requirement in MIP51) The MIP version on the forum matches the version on Github and the MIPs portal That the MIP contains no significant risks/changes that require highlighting to the Maker Community/Delegates prior to a vote Where appropriate, it is confirmed with the MIP author whether eligible MIPs are to be submitted as a MIP set or as individual MIPs A ratification poll is written - largely template based but still takes a bit of time to ensure accuracy - it is much easier to batch the formal submissions and split between 1-3 poll writers, rather than writing them as the formal submissions roll in, to try and prevent any proposals being missed The ratification poll is checked by another member of GovAlpha for accuracy If the first check was not done by a facilitator, a final check is performed by a GovAlpha facilitator to ensure it meets the standards to be submitted to the voting portal If any of the above checks highlight changes are required, these need to be made, and this can cause delays in a team that works async The poll is submitted by a GovAlpha facilitator to the voting portal, such that it will be available at 16:00 UTC on the Monday for voting Appropriate changes are made by a GovAlpha facilitator to the relevant json file to allow the voting portal to display relevant tags  This is just to highlight that although it may seem like “dead time” - there is stuff happening “behind the scenes” and once the weekend is accounted for, there isn’t necessarily a whole lot of wiggle room to get things ready for submission when async working and other responsibilities are factored in. Any reduction in this timeframe should consider what needs to happen on the backend to get a MIP up on the voting portal. This time also allows a cooling-off period for a MIP author to retract formal submission - see MIP65 for a recent example where this happened.
